title: Journal launches election manifesto to present voice of business at General Election
text:

The Journal has launched a General Election manifesto to ensure that the voice of businesses in the North East is heard in the election debate. 
The manifesto will be based on a survey of companies in the region which asks them to rank issues affecting businesses in terms of priority. 
The survey lists issues including devolution, skills, infrastructure, Brexit and the Northern Powerhouse, while people taking part can also add in any issues of their own that they feel are important. Prime Minister Theresa May having some chips while on a walkabout during a election campaign stop in Mevagissey, Cornwall (Photo: PA) 
The survey was launched at last week’s North East Business Awards and will be open over the next few weeks, with results compiled by the end of May so that the findings can be sent to candidates standing in June’s General Election in all the North East constituencies. 
Journal business editor Graeme Whitfield said: “Every General Election is important, but the vote in June comes at a time when some of the most important decisions facing the business community are up for debate. Liberal Democrats leader Tim Farron pets cockapoo dog 'Bonnie' whilst campaigning for the British general election at Eastfield regeneration site on April 27, 2017 in Cambridge, England (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
“I know from the conversations I’ve had with many business people in the North East that the election campaign so far has left them cold. The political parties are more determined than ever before to stage-manage their campaigns and avoid speaking to the public. 
“We want to make sure that the voice of the business community is not ignored. All of the candidates standing for election in our region should be able to say how their policies will affect the companies that are so important to our economy. 
“Our manifesto will enable us to hold the political parties to account both in the run-up to the election and afterwards, as the next Government plots the country’s path towards Brexit and beyond.” Labour party leader, Jeremy Corbyn, waits foir a householder to answer the door as he canvasses for votes on the streets of Warrington on April 22, 2017 in Warrington, United Kingdom (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
The manifesto survey is based around 12 key issues for North East businesses, with participants asked to rate them as high, medium or low priorities. 
Among the issues raised are improvements to transport and IT infrastructure, devolution for the North East, access to European markets and labour after Brexit, and reforming business rates. 
With none of the political parties having yet published their manifestos, it is unclear what their exact policies on business will be. 
Prime Minister Theresa May has spoken of plans to protect workers’ pensions from irresponsible bosses, while Labour has floated a number of policies designed to tackle the problems businesses are caused by late payment. The Lib Dems have made Brexit and securing access to trade in Europe a key part of their election campaign. 
The survey can be found at www.chroniclelive.co.uk/manifesto . Like us on Facebook
